values.alignmentText: Belgium's Brussels/Antwerp .NET market is healthy: steady enterprise roles and EU projects; multilingual teams are common; hybrid/remote options exist.
Belgium 2D Environmental Artist pay is about 20% below top hubs. EU grants and remote work help balance the gap for this family.
Belgium (Brussels, Ghent, Antwerp) has occasional 2D environmental art courses and local meetups; remote options help keep skills current.
Belgium has several strong art/design programs (LUCA, KASK, RITCS) feeding 2D environmental art. The pipeline is solid but niche, with growth potential.
Belgian game studios (Brussels/Ghent) typically require 2-3 months to hire a 2D Environmental Artist; consider remote/global sourcing and relocation support.
Belgium studios widely use English, especially in Brussels; teams are often bilingual, but basic Dutch/French helps.
In Belgium, studios often offer hybrid 2D environmental art roles. Remote work is negotiable; expect occasional onsite in Brussels or Antwerp.
Belgium offers a solid 2D environmental artist pool (Ghent/Brussels/Antwerp); strong mid-level talent with competitive senior hiring in key studios.
Belgium's 3D animator pay aligns with global medians after cost of living; BE (Brussels region) offers strong benefits to ease family relocation.
Belgium offers regular 3D animation workshops and short courses through universities and private schools (Brussels, Ghent), with solid instructors and accessible online options.
Belgium has several animation programs (Ghent/Brussels) with studio ties; class sizes are small, often requiring on-the-job upskilling.
Belgium 3D animator roles usually take 3–4 months; EU talent helps, but niche skills and relocation may be needed.
Belgian 3D studios widely use English; basic Dutch/French helps onboarding. Your English-first preference fits Belgium's multilingual animation scene.
Remote/hybrid 3D animator roles are common in Belgium's game studios (Brussels, Ghent, Antwerp); many offer hybrid schedules and equipment stipends.
Belgium has a moderate 3D animation pool, centered in Brussels/Ghent; startups may need longer searches or relocation for senior roles.
Belgium (Brussels region): 3D character artist pay trails top markets by 25–30%. Strong social benefits and EU programs help offset for families.
Belgium (Ghent/Brussels) has regular 3D character art workshops and short courses. Solid instructors and accessible formats support local upskilling.
Belgium has serviceable 3D animation programs, but no large pipeline; studios bridge gaps with internships.
In Belgium, 3D character artist roles typically take 4-5 months with multiple search cycles. Local pipelines are shallow, so remote talent helps.
Belgian studios commonly use English; Dutch/French basics help with locals. Your English-first approach fits, and you're open to learning the local language.
In Belgium, 3D Character Artist roles are remote/hybrid on a case-by-case basis; expect occasional on-site work in BE studios and flexible hours.
Belgium (Ghent/Brussels) has a strong 3D character artist pool with Larian and studios; mid-to-senior talent readily available.
Belgium has generalist accelerators (e.g., imec.istart, Co.Station Brussels) with limited game-specific tracks; expect annual cohorts rather than dedicated game programs.
Belgian urban air is good overall with LEZs; NO2 spikes persist by ring roads in Brussels/Antwerp; portable filters on high-pollen days help.
Belgium hosts Larian Studios in Ghent as a notable anchor; additional regional studios provide steady, but varied, game dev opportunities.
Belgium is largely secular; atheism is mainstream, with open participation in secular public life and minimal religious friction.
Belgium (BE) benefits from EU oversight and independent courts; backsliding risk remains low, with strong civil liberties for families.
In Belgium/EU, banking is modern: SEPA/IBAN, instant payments, and easy expat account setup; cross-border needs well supported.
Belgian North Sea beaches offer family-friendly dunes and boardwalks; cool water and a short summer bathing window, with good cycling/walking.
Active boardgame cafes and clubs in Brussels/Antwerp/Ghent; family-friendly events and a thriving hobby scene in Belgium.
In Belgium, body positivity is common and public discourse is less stigmatizing. Boundaries help families keep fitness talk respectful.
Belgium's diversified economy across tech, services, and manufacturing supports stable hiring; layoffs are brief and reemployment is common.
Belgium cancer incidence aligns with Western European norms; strong screening and universal healthcare support early detection for your family.
In Belgium, prisons meet high EU standards with strong oversight; humane conditions and restorative programs fit our rights-focused family.
Belgium offers subsidized creches and regional family allowances; reliable options exist, but waitlists are common—plan early for both kids.
Belgian cities are safe, walkable, with parks and strong public transport; family-friendly districts in Brussels, Ghent, and Leuven suit kids well.
Belgium provides substantial childcare subsidies and parental leave; fees are largely covered, with nearby crèches for both kids.
Belgium: non-EU visa families can access childcare subsidies after registration; regional timelines vary, so expect some processing.
Belgian life features cycling, football, hiking and festivals as common pastimes. Board-game cafés and climbing gyms fit the family's gaming and activity interests.
Belgium has regular monthly meetups and occasional game jams in Brussels and Ghent; events like FOSDEM fuel a connected dev community.
Belgium offers strong preventive care and accessible health services. A health-conscious, family-friendly culture aligns with Trey and Sarah's priorities.
Belgium has a small but established co-housing scene in Brussels, Ghent and Antwerp. Some projects welcome families, but entry is selective and patience helps.
In Belgium, community manager pay typically tracks global medians after cost of living; strong benefits and EU grants suit a founder-friendly, hybrid setup.
Belgium has sporadic continuing education for community managers; occasional events and remote options exist in Brussels/Antwerp, no steady local hub.
Belgium has niche community manager tracks in marketing/communications; cohorts are small and bilingual study is common, with English-taught options at major universities.
Belgium: Community Manager hiring typically 3-4 months; leverage remote/hybrid options to widen local/European pools (Brussels/Ghent).
Belgium (BE): English is widely used in studios, but basic Dutch/French skills help community work.
Belgian studios commonly support hybrid/remote roles with robust async workflows; suitable for a family-friendly setup in Belgium with remote-friendly policies.
Belgium has a solid community manager pool anchored by Ghent/Brussels studios; senior hires are competitive, relocation or remote options may be needed.
Brussels, Belgium, is expat-friendly with multilingual communities. Language circles and local groups help newcomers integrate.
Compensation in Belgium tracks EU medians with cost-of-living adjustments. Strong benefits and healthcare help families; expect negotiation for extras.
Belgian startup compensation blends solid base pay with meaningful equity; EU incentives help extend runway for a family of four.
In Belgium, register with the commune, join a mutualité, and file annual taxes; some regions may require integration courses; expect periodic checks.
Belgium offers regular bootcamps and meetups in web/game dev and cloud; Brussels and Leuven host strong continuing education options.
Belgium has a solid IT contractor bench with EU-wide game dev and Azure talent; some scarcity for top specialists; onboarding may take several weeks.
Belgium (BE) favors harm-reduction: small-quantity possession is administrative with fines; strong healthcare and support help substance issues.
Belgium offers strong talent and grants, but payroll taxes and Brussels rents push costs about 15-20% above peers, tightening runway.
Brussels 3-bedroom rents around €1,700–€2,000 with notable energy costs. Ghent/Leuven offer more affordable, family-friendly options.
Belgium offers solid coworking in Brussels and Ghent with a startup scene; game-dev ecosystem exists, but mocap/audio labs are scarce for indies.
Belgium's tech market is solid, with broad English use and good EU grants. For game dev and web roles, expect slight scarcity; remote work helps.
Belgium's universal healthcare offers accessible mental health services and open dialogue; depression rates are relatively low and English-friendly care exists.
Belgium's expat-friendly, club-based scene supports gradual deep bonds for this two-adult, two-child family. Steady outreach and language learning pay off.
Belgium's D&I is strong: LGBTQ+ protections, multilingual inclusivity, and progressive work norms; supportive for a family-focused migration.
In Belgium, enforcement focuses on trafficking and violence; users receive support and diversion programs.
Belgium (BE) permits dual US citizenship with minimal paperwork. You can keep both as you settle in BE.
Belgium offers solid game-dev grants (Brussels/Flanders) and EU funds; ~350k-700k accessible for Trey's startup, though competitive.
Belgium offers public grants and generalist VC; games can access EU funds, but local game-specific backers are limited; prepare for competitive funding.
Belgium's solid services/logistics economy and strong safety nets support families like ours; occasional sector slumps mean we should keep emergency savings.
Belgium’s social market economy blends innovation with strong safety nets and reliable governance, supporting families and startups in BE.
Belgium offers stable, EU-aligned policy with predictable funding for game dev and regional subsidies. Occasional shifts exist, but overall it's manageable.
Belgian education is generally strong; Brussels and Flanders offer robust bilingual tracks, but outcomes vary by commune.
Belgium offers several accredited game programs (Howest, LUCA, KASK) with studio ties (Larian in Ghent) and internships.
Belgium offers EU Blue Card/Single Permit sponsorship; many ICT employers sponsor and include dependents without drama. Founders may face constraints; Sarah's role fits readily.
Belgium hosts a strong Unity scene with active Unreal groups. Other engines also have communities, enabling cross-engine collaboration.
Belgium's strong environmental rules and green spaces give high quality overall. Some urban pollution hotspots exist, but nature access remains easy.
Belgium (BE): dual-income family tax around 40%-45% effective; strong public services and child benefits help offset costs.
Belgian autumn is typically 10-15 C with rain; most days are mild with light sweater weather. Expect occasional drizzle and sunny breaks.
Belgium offers parks, cycling culture, and strong family services including childcare and universal healthcare. Multilingual schools and high QoL support families.
Belgium offers core family reunification for a spouse and two minors with required documents. Some bureaucracy is expected, but immediate family qualifies.
Belgium provides robust parental leave, child benefits, and subsidized childcare; regional rules can slow access and vary by region.
Belgium provides strong family supports: universal healthcare, child allowances, and subsidized childcare; some programs require paperwork or income caps.
Belgium provides healthcare and some child benefits to visa holders after residency. Initial access is opaque and often requires HR or immigration guidance.
Belgium (Brussels) favors smart-casual in urban settings; polished looks fit work and city life, but family spaces remain relaxed.
Belgian urban fashion (Brussels/Antwerp) is inclusive and body-positive; women wear diverse styles with freedom in daily life and work.
Belgian urban life (Brussels) favors modern smart-casual; cycling-ready footwear and practical layers suit daily commutes.
Belgium supports diverse femininity with strong gender equality; urban life offers autonomy, with only minor conservative pockets.
Belgium has strict gun laws: licensing, secure storage, and training; ownership exists but is tightly regulated, keeping public spaces safe.
Belgium's consent culture is strong; in BE, boundaries are checked and respected, though alcohol-influenced scenes still require vigilance around families.
Belgium has a growing founder scene (Brussels/Leuven/Ghent) with regular meetups and accelerators; grants exist, mentorship varies.
In Belgium, especially Brussels and larger towns, fresh markets and diverse cuisines are plentiful; rural areas may require occasional trips.
Belgium locals are polite and open when we reach out; expect gradual friendships as we settle in and engage with neighborhoods and schools.
In Belgium, expect roughly €100k–€250k/year in game-dev grants via regional/EU programs. Be prepared for competition and reporting.
Belgium's game dev scene is active (Ghent/Brussels); steady openings in mid-size studios and indies, with opportunities concentrated in major cities.
In Belgium (BE), social acceptance is strong with active LGBTQ+ groups; some official documents lag behind lived protections.
Belgium has strong gender-rights protections, EU-aligned laws, and active enforcement with broad social acceptance for LGBTQ+ and family rights.
Belgium's strong gender-equality policies support shared caregiving. Our BE profile shows both parents working with flexible, family-friendly options.
Belgium BE, especially Brussels/Antwerp, is broadly inclusive; all genders can initiate without stigma, with rare lingering traditional cues in nightlife.
Belgium offers solid family protections, but non-EU founder visas depend on renewals. Bureaucracy exists, yet healthcare and schools are strong.
Belgium's climate is mild with occasional heatwaves and river flood risk. Strong infrastructure and planning help keep the risk manageable for families.
Belgium offers startup visa routes with incubator support; expect paperwork and quotas; timing can vary, but accessible for founders.
Belgium (BE) favors polished practicality. We stay neat for work and social settings without overinvesting.
Belgium's progressive scenes tolerate polyamory; social services may lack formal frameworks, so discretion is wise in official processes.
Belgium's universal health system covers most costs. Pediatric care is accessible with modest co-pays and generally short wait times.
Belgium offers universal care via mutualité; visa holders can enroll after arrival, with private insurance advisable during the initial period.
Belgian public universities offer subsidized tuition with grants/loans. Access for non-EU residents exists but varies; local networks help.
Belgian public universities charge higher fees for non-EU visa holders. Scholarships exist but are selective; post-study work options can help stay.
Belgium (Brussels/Flanders) hiring is moderate; 3–4 months to fill roles, with remote options; fits Trey/Sarah plans.
Belgium: early-stage hires typically take about 3 months as candidates weigh risk; EU funds (VAF/Gamefonds) and English-friendly tech roles aid attraction.
Belgium (BE): outside Brussels offers moderate prices and tightening energy standards; expect competition and paperwork for family-friendly rentals.
Belgium uses PAYE with annual returns; progressive tax and social contributions; online Tax-on-Web helps families, though yearly changes require vigilance.
Belgium's multilingual communities are broadly welcoming; language rights and social services support families, with occasional immigration debates.
In Belgium, White US migrants who learn Dutch/French and engage locally are welcomed, but reception still hinges on class and language.
Belgium (BE) offers strong public K-12 with language support. Many regions provide bilingual options; transfers are generally straightforward.
Belgium: visa-holding children can enroll in public schools with language support; residency documentation required; access comparable to citizens.
In Belgium's Brussels region, English is common, but schooling/paperwork favor Dutch or French; plan local-language study for full participation.
Belgian studios use English for cross-border work; local Dutch/French fluency remains important for community, compliance, and partnerships in BE.
Belgian startups commonly run in English, with strong local-language (Dutch/French) support; bilingual operations are feasible with translation budgets.
Belgium has several tech/IP firms with game-IP know-how; Brussels/Antwerp hubs offer options; startup pricing varies but generally workable.
Belgium (BE) offers strong LGBTQ+ protections with anti-discrimination laws; urban areas celebrate Pride, rural areas may be more cautious.
Belgium hosts active indie game scenes in Brussels/Ghent/Antwerp; reliable playtests exist but scheduling may require lead time; English-friendly testers.
In Belgium, Marxism is discussed mainly in academia and unions; not mainstream, but tolerated and present in niche circles.
In Belgium, masculinity norms are broad; Trey can be nurturing and share caregiving with Sarah without stigma.
Belgium has occasional regional incidents (e.g., Brussels). Stay situationally aware at large gatherings, but overall safety is solid.
Brussels-area meetups are plentiful across tech, NGOs, parenting, and hobbies; most events are accessible, though some niches use waitlists or fees.
Belgium's minimum wage plus strong family benefits generally covers core needs for a four-person family; urban living costs can stretch the budget.
Belgium offers reliable broadband/5G and strong digital services; urban areas run smoothly with minimal outages, though some rural gaps remain.
Belgium (BE) offers supportive polyamory subcultures; mainstream spaces are tolerant if discretion is maintained.
In Belgium, direct but tactful, open dialogue is valued; share needs clearly while respecting local etiquette and multilingual realities.
Belgium's Ardennes, Flemish countryside, and coast dunes offer stunning scenery with well-maintained trails; ideal for weekly family outings in mild seasons.
Belgium experiences floods, windstorms, and heatwaves every few years; robust EU infrastructure and alerts keep disruption manageable for families.
Excellent nature access in Belgium: Soignes Forest near Brussels within minutes by transit; family-friendly Ardennes trails within a few hours by car.
Brussels/Antwerp/Ghent host strong live music and year-round festivals. Family-friendly daytime events exist; plan trips for late-night venues in Belgium.
Nightlife exists in Brussels/Antwerp/Ghent; plan sitters and safe transport for evenings. Smaller towns are quieter, which suits family life.
Brussels, Antwerp and Ghent host regular game dev meetups and jams; easy access to EU events nearby; welcoming to newcomers and families.
Belgium hosts Larian (Ghent) and Happy Volcano, anchoring a solid BE game scene. Proximity to Brussels and other EU hubs aids networking and grants access.
Belgium (BE) obesity levels are moderate; public health campaigns and active transport help keep trends stable.
Belgium offers game-startup funding via VAF and screen.brussels plus EU programs; EU publisher access is solid. Startups still require capital or co-founders.
Belgium's pace varies; Brussels is brisk. Regional towns and suburbs offer a calmer, family-friendly rhythm.
Belgium (BE) supports dual parenting and normal paternal leave; schools partner with families and bilingual education aligns with this profile.
Belgium allows naturalization after about 5 years of legal residence with language/integration proof; dual citizenship is possible for families like yours.
Very low corruption perception in Belgium; strong oversight and effective investigations, with EU institutions enhancing transparency.
Belgium (BE); in Brussels transit and markets can feel crowded. Most locals respect boundaries, but you may encounter closer contact in crowds.
Belgium generally respects personal space; greetings are often handshakes with occasional cheek-kisses. We keep touch polite and minimal.
Belgium has mild year-round temps but frequent rain. Outdoor days peak in spring and autumn; plan for showers.
Belgium has a constitutional monarchy with federal parliamentary democracy; governance is stable but coalition politics can slow reform.
Belgium (BE) shows private acceptance for polyamorous families, but mainstream services may misunderstand; discretion advised in work/school.
Strong subsidized childcare network in Belgium; creches 0-3 and maternelle from ~2.5, but urban waitlists vary by commune.
Private/intl schools exist in Brussels/Antwerp; fees are high and quality varies; scrutinize accreditation and values.
Belgium (BE) has strong fresh markets in cities. Processed foods are common, but planning helps the family prioritize fresh options.
Belgium (BE): Product Marketing Manager (Games) pay trails top markets by 25-30%; strong healthcare and work-life balance offset the gap for families.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: Belgium offers sporadic game-marketing upskilling; Brussels/Ghent host occasional events; most learning remains self-directed.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: Belgium has limited but emerging game-marketing programs. Small cohorts near Ghent (Larian) offer on-the-job upskilling.
Belgium's growing games/tech scene (Brussels/Ghent) with English-friendly business climate. Plan 3-4 months to hire a PMM (Games) needing relocation/visa.
Belgian game marketing uses English widely; local Dutch/French skills help for client-facing work.
Belgian game studios widely support hybrid/remote PMMs; expect on-site meetings in Brussels/Ghent; equipment stipends are common.
Belgium PMM (games) pool is solid but concentrated in a few studios (Larian, Ubisoft Belgium); senior talent is competitive—relocation or remote hiring may be needed.
Belgium's progressive, rights-based society with universal healthcare and strong schools fits this family's values; English-friendly and a mild climate.
Attitudes in Belgium are split; urban centers (Brussels/Antwerp) favor openness about sexuality, incl. non-monogamy; rural areas remain more reserved.
Belgian media offers diverse, independent outlets; reporting aims for factual coverage with minimal propaganda and inclusive civic participation.
Belgium has a broadly free media landscape with watchdogs. Propaganda is occasional and quickly countered by independent outlets.
Belgian cities (Brussels/Antwerp) offer trams, buses, trains with real-time apps and bike links; strong urban transit, weekend frequency may dip.
Belgium hosts EU-focused dev events and some platform reps in Brussels/Ghent. Partnerships exist but proactive outreach is needed to connect with BE publishers.
In Belgium, high earners access strong healthcare and schools; English-friendly Brussels helps expats, but elite services require planning and early booking.
Belgium BE: With universal healthcare and childcare support, two-kid families manage basics; housing in cities can strain budgets, but public services cushion costs.
In Belgium (BE), a comfortable life with two kids is feasible thanks to universal healthcare, but housing and childcare costs require budgeting.
Belgium's real-time game scene (Brussels/Ghent) blends strong cinematic pipelines with EU grants and solid broadband. This supports Trey's studio goals.
In Belgium (BE), religion influences culture but policy remains secular, evidence-based, and pluralistic; your progressive, family-first values fit well.
Belgian studios mix onsite work with hybrid options. Remote is allowed case-by-case, with a preference for hybrid presence.
Belgian startups are hybrid-friendly with mature remote tooling. This fits Trey's founder role and Sarah's remote-friendly web work.
Remote work is broadly accepted in Belgium, with Brussels/Ghent coworking; hybrid options help work-life balance, though some roles require office days.
Belgium offers family reunification and work permits; initial permits need income/housing proof; permanent residency after ~5 years.
Belgium offers a stable IT sector and family-friendly policies; likely good retention for skilled adults like Trey and Sarah with remote/hybrid work.
Belgian public pension is solid but depends on lifelong contributions. Pillar II/III pensions provide additional security for retirees.
Belgium offers a public pension to long-term residents with contributions; visa holders gain eligibility after years of work, though returns may be modest.
Belgium's Ruby market exists but clusters in a few startups; network actively in Brussels/Antwerp to access remote or hybrid roles.
Belgium (BE) is generally safe for families. Petty theft occurs in tourist cores; exercise standard precautions after dark in city centers.
Belgium offers public schooling by language communities (Dutch/French); Brussels has bilingual programs, with admissions requiring planning.
Belgian coast water is cool (18-20 C) for most of the year; summers feel mild, but early summer wetsuits help kids.
Belgium's seasons are mild with regular rain. A couple notable extremes (storms, chilly snaps) per season require gear and planning for families.
In Belgium, grey winters bring noticeable darkness. Keep energy with regular outdoor breaks and, if needed, light therapy.
Belgium's temperate maritime climate offers mild summers and cool, rainy winters. Seasonal swings are manageable with light gear.
Belgium's senior tech pool is limited; startups often hire abroad or remote. Brussels and Leuven offer strong talent, but competition remains.
Belgium offers comprehensive sex education and destigmatized attitudes. Open media and liberal attitudes prevail in cities; rural areas vary.
Belgium's universal healthcare and strong child benefits in BE align with family needs; education is solid, though immigration steps can be bureaucratic.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: In Belgium (Brussels/Antwerp), 2k sq ft rentals exist but are pricey. Expect fast competition and broker help to secure space.
Belgium spring usually 12-22 C with brief chilly rain bursts. By late spring, more sun appears, so light layers suffice.
Stable overall in Belgium with coalition talks; regional disparities between Flanders and Wallonia create occasional tensions, but daily life stays steady.
Belgium’s pluralist, rights-based governance with centrist coalitions; pragmatic, evidence-led policymaking in BE.
Belgium's social market economy blends innovation with strong safety nets and fair competition, supporting families with universal healthcare and schools.
Belgium shows a moderate studio presence anchored in Ghent and Brussels; Larian is a flagship studio with a few smaller firms nearby.
Belgium summer highs ~22–25°C with occasional 30°C heatwaves. Humidity is moderate and coastal areas stay cooler.
Belgian service is polite but situational; initiate friendly chats and expect mostly responsive staff, especially in multilingual urban areas like Brussels.
Belgium offers tax shelters for audiovisual/creative works with caps and varying funding; games may qualify but access windows vary.
In Belgium (BE), family long-stay visas typically take about 9 months with manageable fees; commune-level processing varies.
Belgium's government trust is mixed; regional dynamics (Flanders/Wallonia) shape confidence in services and transparency.
Belgium has low systemic corruption; procurement/local issues exist but are well managed by strong oversight in Brussels.
Belgian salaries are strong but lag NL/DE; good benefits and EU startup grants help founders—remote work or dual incomes keep it comfortable.
Belgian weekends offer markets, parks, and family-friendly cycling in cities. Sunday shop hours vary, but cafes and festivals are easy to enjoy with kids.
Belgium: school ~8:30-15:30; workdays ~9-17; wraparound daycare/after-care varies by commune; remote/hybrid helps balance.
Belgium offers about 30 paid days (20 vacation + 10 holidays) with strong enforcement. Unused days are typically paid out when leaving.
Belgium typically offers around 30 vacation days (20 annual leave + 10 public holidays); plenty of downtime for family trips.
Belgium has a modest vendor scene; a few trusted art/QA agencies exist, but full game-dev outsourcing often relies on remote partners.
In Belgium (BE), real-time VFX pay is ~20% below global medians; strong benefits and work-life balance help offset the gap.
Belgium: occasional VFX real-time training with local events and visiting experts; online courses help fill gaps; some universities offer related programs.
Belgium has 1–2 reputable VFX (real-time) programs feeding grads into regional studios; EU partnerships bolster ongoing pipelines.
Belgium real-time VFX roles typically take 4-5 months; cross-border and remote candidates help fill positions, aided by EU mobility.
Belgium BE: English is widely used in VFX studios; basic Dutch or French helps in Brussels and surrounding regions.
Belgium (Brussels area): hybrid real-time VFX is common; fully remote setups usually require negotiation.
Belgium's real-time VFX talent pool is moderate, with pockets in Brussels and Ghent. Senior hires may require relocation or remote options.
Belgium (BE) enjoys open borders with NL/FR/DE/LU and easy cross-border travel; EU ties boost stable, multilingual daily life.
Belgium is multilingual and pragmatic; emphasizes welfare and EU collaboration. This aligns with our family's inclusive, community-driven priorities in Belgium.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Belgium is viewed as a solid EU partner; Brussels is the administrative hub, with neighbors respecting its economy but watching policy nuances.
Belgium offers EU Blue Card, Single Permit, and self-employed routes. Startup visa options exist but require solid plans and funding.
Belgian cities have strong sidewalks and good transit, but busy corridors require alertness with kids; plan routes to avoid arterial streets.
Belgium's Brussels expat scene is welcoming to US families, though many Flemish towns expect Dutch and slower integration.
Belgium's multilingual, family-friendly culture centers in Brussels; great cycling and easy cross-border travel, with English-friendly services.
Belgian winters are cool (~0-7 C) with damp days. Regular frosts and Ardennes snow; heating costs remain manageable.
Belgium's standard workweek is about 38 hours with flex-time options, matching the family's preference for predictable, family-friendly hours in BE.
Belgium's 38–40h workweek and generous leave support Sarah's family-friendly goals. Flexible hours are common, though peak periods may require planning.
Belgium's robust worker protections and active unions offer solid rights and recourse for tech teams; expect clear rules and stable employment in BE.
